ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live, recorded virtual lecture.
I can manage the combination of virtual and in-person lecture.
Lectures were also recorded and posted.
None.
We had videos of class before to watch, so it was a flipped classroom setting.
none
in-person lecture, recorded lecture
Website named Ximera with practice problems; short YouTube videos from the professor
There were online quizzes and pre-class lectures with questions.
revision of past papers and text book questions

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely none, aside how to use outside resources to teach myself material.
As I am a graduate student, this course helped me to make a foundation to excel in my quantitative skills.
I learned how to use outside resources to benefit my learning.

Through taking this course, I gained a sufficient knowledge of single-variable calculus, and working through this course despite the circumstances required all students to develop perseverance. The mastery-based grading system allowed me to pave my own path and understand what I personally needed to work on compared to the typical exam-oriented course structure.
I developed quantitative critical thinking skills and learned calculus of a single variable.
I learned a lot of about Calc 1, limits, derivatives, integrals, etc.

I did not learn that many new skills or knowledge to be honest. The course was pretty terribly taught and provided very little to support to students learning virtually. I basically had to teach myself everything because the instructors could not clearly explain any of the course content.
Calc
How to think critically about how to solve math problems using the same concepts learned in lecture but in much disguised word problems.
I became much more comfortable with calculus in this course. I already had a background in a lot of the subjects that we went over, but it was great to go over it again and become more adept
Calculus of function of one variable; problem set planning (doing a little day-by-day)
Introductory Level Calculus. All the skills listed on the syllabus are exactly what you learn.

Overall I became more confident in my math abilities. I learned how to evaluate integrals and derivatives. I had taken AP Calc AB in high school, and all the material in this class was essentially the same. The only difference is that Professor Edwards took the time to show us the proofs for certain concepts which allowed me to appreciate calculus more.
a more thorough understanding of calculus

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course instructor was completely not engaging, unaware, and slow. He made no effort to engage the class and in many of the lectures, he arrived 5 minutes late. The material was poorly explained, the method of grading was convoluted, and the instructor struggled to explain material in class and in office hours, especially when questions rose up about the class structure. The instructor did not know why I received certain grades for assignments and struggled to explain my grades to me -- the course was led by a group, headed by a lead-instructor, whom my professor refused to advocate student concerns to.

Strengths: well structured and comprehensive
Weaknesses: A heavy load of practice problems and HAMs; however I enjoyed solving those.

I feel like there was an extreme lack of feedback from the course, which made it impossible to improve your abilities on topics you may have performed poorly on. There was also no interaction between the students, which made the class seem disconnected. I also believe that the lectures we watched did not translate to the work that had to be done.

Virtual office hours were available and very helpful. It was also helpful to have recorded lectures that were promptly posted on Canvas. The live virtual class sometimes lacked engagement with the students.

Strengths: moderate workload and good pacing, pre-lecture videos were short and helped provide a topic introduction for the upcoming class
Weakness: lecture was unengaging and didn't always prepare me for PSETS
Improvements: part of lecture should be dedicated to problems and ideas related to the PSETs

The class was nice because we went over a lot of cool topics, but the way the professor taught was very long and boring as we kind of did only practice problems the whole time. The way that class is graded is definitely a strength, as it was very low stress, which was so nice.

The teaching itself was just not good. I basically had to teach myself everything. However the ability to take several quizzes was appropiate and effective especially since students had to learn all the content by themselves this term.
The professor was very slow.

Strengths: preclass assignments gave me a great idea about the information we were going to learn and made me pay attention with the quizzes. Another strength is that this course was based on mastery levels. I really enjoyed having multiple attempts. This mastery approach allowed me to see my mistakes and learn from them rather than a midterm or final and i just move on without correcting

Weakness: The lectures from class and P-set and even some of the HAM and Quiz did not match up at all. In most cases, the pset did not corroclate at all with what we did in lecture. Or at least is was very difficult.
This course had really low engagement. Everyday was packed with learning, and examples which is informative but a little bit dull
Thought the mastery system was great. I think smaller assignments assigned more frequently would be more beneficial than larger, once-a-week assignments.

The strengths of this course are the setup of the mastery-based grading. However, a weakness of this course may be the way problem sets take up a majority of our time outside class but often are not that helpful for the quizzes which are more important for our grade.

Strengths: I really loved this mastery based grading system. It made the class low stress and manageable. 
Weaknesses: It would have been nice to have wider windows to take the quizzes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The entire course was made worse by way of the pandemic. The recorded lecture did help for review, though.
Break out rooms seems a good option for interaction but that should be led by professor or TAs.

The lectures were informative, even online. I think the disconnection between the students made it difficult to form study groups or other group learning, which would've made it easier to learn the material.
Office hours and lectures were conducted over zoom and assignments/quizzes were completed on CANVAS. These practices worked well for the class.
Online was definitely detrimental to learning. It was so hard to stay engaged, and often I'd get zoned out during class.

There were virtually no practice problems or guided support to help students better learn the material. The lesson plans were very dense and extremely high level/unclear especially for a Calculus 1 course. Students had to put in enormous effort outside of class to relearn or teach themselves the material that was overcomplicated or glazed over during class time. Additionally the in class actives were extremely difficult, made literally no sense, and did not contribute to a greater understanding of the material. For a student interested or intending to use mathematics in the future, this course was incredibly disappointing.

Continuing the office hours helped greatly with pset and answering questions from lecture. Also office hours with the professor really aided in my success. 

Other than that, I feel like as long as you take advantage to ask your questions like i did in the office hours and schedule meetings with Professor, the class was a success.
Zoom definitely failed in this course. Our course had very low engagement, and it was mostly staring at a computer screen with letters and numbers on it the whole time
Office hours were very helpful, and it was somewhat convenient they were virtual. Class, in general, was not to engaging and few students ever had their cameras on.

I think the lecture format which allowed us to ask questions during class worked. I really really liked being able to attend office hours through zoom - I hope that can still be an option once things go back to normal.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely not. The professor was horrible at teaching and was unable to explain material. The workload was intense and did not reflect the material presented in class.
I would recommend this course to those graduate students who want to build calculus skills.
I would recommend this course to another student if feedback from the graders improves. This class was informative, but it did not allow for improvement after error.
Only if required and minimal to no prior knowledge of calculus is known.
Yes, if they would like to learn more about Calc 112.
if you have to take this course then sure fine, do what you have to do. But expect, especially if this is your first time taking math in college, to be teaching yourself a majority of the material.
Not really. Course was hard to engage with and boring.

Yes, the most appealing characterisitic of this course is the mastery approach. All the stress and anxiety of finals and midterms is alleviated due to this mastery approach. you have multiple opportunites to learn, correct, and understand what you learn.
Yes I would recommend this course because it is very fundamental and has important concepts. If you need a refresher on calculus in college I would highly recommend
Yes, I like its setup and didn't mind coming to class.

Yes. If you are completely unfamiliar with calculus this class will teach you all you need honestly. If you don't understand something honestly the tutors are heaven-sent just go to them. Also, study before your quizzes. You wanna make sure you study the right thing tho because sometimes what you learned that week won't be on the quiz but it'll actually be last week's content.
Yes, although this was to me a (much easier) repeat of AP calc AB, I think it served as a nice refresher and allowed me as a first-year to ease into QR classes at Yale.
